<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FDGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_FDGetInfo(osal_id_t filedes, OS_file_prop_t *fd_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(fd_prop);

    memset(fd_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_file_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            strncpy(fd_prop->Path, record->name_entry, sizeof(fd_prop->Path) - 1);
        }
        fd_prop->User    = record->creator;
        fd_prop->IsValid = true;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strncpy(fd_prop->Path, record->name_entry, sizeof(fd_prop->Path) - 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Although the call uses sizeof(fd_prop->Path) - 1 which prevents writing past the destination (the destination was also zeroed earlier), the code does not ensure that the source object (record->name_entry) has at least that many accessible bytes or contains a NUL within that bound. If record->name_entry points to a shorter/non-NUL-terminated buffer, strncpy may read beyond the bounds of the source object. Therefore the use of strncpy here can result in out-of-bounds access of the source and violates Rule 21.17.
